description.value: The Austrian Research Promotion Agency (FFG) is the national funding institution for business-related research and development in Austria. FFG's funding programs utilize harmonized funding instruments to support various project types. These instruments aim to foster research, development, and innovation across different constellations and project stages. The FFG provides support for exploring R&D topics, executing concrete R&D projects, market introduction of R&D results, and building research and innovation infrastructures.

eligibility.value: Companies and organizations based in Austria
The program targets the creation of new spin-off companies from research institutions, implying early-stage or pre-incorporation companies.

Fellows are researchers from Austrian universities and research institutions (e.g., University of Applied Sciences Technikum Wien, Technical University of Leoben, Medical University of Vienna, TU Wien, BOKU University Vienna, Graz University of Technology, Austrian Academy of Sciences, University of Graz, University of Vienna, University of Innsbruck, Institute of Science and Technology Austria, FH OÖ Forschungs & Entwicklungs GmbH, University of Klagenfurt, University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences, AIT Austrian Institute of Technology GmbH, Competence Centre – The Virtual Vehicle Research Company, University of Veterinary Medicine Vienna). The program supports the development of their research into market-ready prototypes or technologies with a view to commercialisation and spin-off creation.

funding_details.value: Funds can be used for developing artificial nerve grafts, innovative methanation technology, sensor systems, mobile EEG prototypes, efficient visual intelligence for autonomous driving, stable production cell lines, circular economy wood construction systems, electro-acoustic spinning technology, sustainable biocides, sensor systems for avalanche monitoring, preclinical drug candidates, wireless sensor systems for building monitoring, machine learning methods for defect detection, sustainable screen printing inks, proton conducting materials for fuel cells, superconducting quantum computer hardware, sustainable syngas production, non-invasive measurement of RF signals on integrated circuits, safe vascular access needles, direct evaluation of tissue-infiltrating lymphocytes, advanced modular software engines for precision molecular imaging, modular sensor fusion for drones, liquid chromatin diagnostics, oncolytic influenza A viruses, polysensory systems for concreting processes, compact ultra-low frequency noise and continuously tunable lasers, yeast as microbial immunosensors, irreversible organic electrochromic inks, efficient production of isotope-labelled amino acids, polyaniline modified catalysts for fuel cells, CO2-fixing yeast as animal feed, electrodynamic manipulation of biological material, new epoxy resin systems with on-demand curing, software for automated analysis of flow cytometer data, continuous high-precision measurement of nanoparticles, new generation of stainless steel powder for additive manufacturing, lysophosphatidylcholine for foulbrood treatment, enzymatic yoghurt alternatives, embroidered textile reinforcements for concrete components, electric fish protection cable screens, functionalisation of quartz microbalances for biomolecule detection, artificial intelligence-based software for price change prediction, energy-saving shower systems, new drugs for acute myeloid leukaemia, and optical measurement systems for gas concentration distribution.

timeline.value: The third round of Spin-off Fellowships had a submission period from 16 May to 24 September 2024.

description.value: EU Missions are large-scale initiatives under Horizon Europe setting clear, time-bound goals that drive focused efforts towards some of our greatest challenges such as climate change, cancer, ocean restoration, soil health, and the development of climate-neutral and smart cities. By bringing together researchers, policymakers, citizens, and stakeholders, EU Missions pool the necessary resources to drive innovation and deliver concrete solutions for societal benefit.

timeline.value: The EU Missions are a novelty of the Horizon Europe research and innovation programme for 2021-2027.

description.value: Horizon Europe is the EU’s key funding programme for research and innovation for the period 2021-2027. It tackles climate change, helps to achieve the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals, and boosts the EU’s competitiveness and growth. The programme facilitates collaboration and strengthens the impact of research and innovation in developing, supporting and implementing EU policies while tackling global challenges. It supports creating and better dispersing of excellent knowledge and technologies, creating jobs, engaging the EU’s talent pool, and optimising investment impact within a strengthened European Research Area.

description.value: The overarching vision behind the proposed investments under Cluster 4 is that of Europe shaping competitive and trusted technologies for a European industry with global leadership in key areas, enabling production and consumption to respect the boundaries of our planet, and maximising the benefits for all parts of society in the variety of social, economic and territorial contexts in Europe. This will build a competitive, digital, low-carbon and circular industry, ensure sustainable supply of raw materials, develop advanced materials and provide the basis for advances and innovation in global challenges to society. The expected impacts of this cluster are contained in the Horizon Europe strategic plan.

description.value: The Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions (MSCA) are the EU's flagship programme for doctoral and postdoctoral training, designed to equip researchers with new knowledge and skills through mobility across borders and exposure to diverse sectors and disciplines. The program funds excellent doctoral and postdoctoral training programmes and collaborative research projects, aiming to enhance researchers’ training and career development systems. MSCA achieves a structuring impact on higher education institutions, research centres, and other organizations by widely spreading excellence and setting high standards for researcher education and training. This initiative boosts the visibility and attractiveness of participating organizations across the European Research Area and globally.

description.value: The EU Cities Mission aims to deliver 100 climate-neutral and smart cities by 2030, ensuring these cities act as experimentation and innovation hubs to enable all European cities to follow suit by 2050. This mission drives Europe’s transition to climate neutrality by supporting 100 cities in the EU and 12 cities in countries associated with Horizon Europe. Cities co-create Climate City Contracts outlining their roadmap to climate neutrality, and those successfully developing these contracts receive the EU Mission Label, which facilitates access to public and private funding. The mission provides around €120 million in annual funding from Horizon Europe, hands-on support, and access to open calls for research and innovation projects.

eligibility.value: 100 cities in the EU and 12 cities in countries associated with Horizon Europe
Cities must successfully develop Climate City Contracts, co-created with local stakeholders and citizens, to receive the EU Mission Label.

max. 1.5 million euros with another private investor

description.value: This cluster aims to improve and protect the health and well-being of citizens of all ages by generating new knowledge and developing innovative solutions. The program also seeks to make public health systems more cost-effective, equitable, and sustainable, and to prevent and tackle poverty-related diseases.

description.value: Work programmes set out funding opportunities under Horizon Europe. One specific programme under Horizon Europe is implemented through Marie Skłodowska-Curie actions and research infrastructures under Pillar I, all clusters under Pillar II, European innovation ecosystems under Pillar III, and the part widening participation and strengthening the European Research Area. Other work programmes cover the European Research Council (ERC), Joint Research Centre (JRC), and European Innovation Council (EIC). A significant part of Pillar II will be implemented through institutionalised partnerships in areas like Mobility, Energy, Digital, and Bio-based economy, each with separate work programmes. The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT), European Defence Fund, and Euratom Research and Training Programme also have their own programming documents.

project.value: Tackles climate change, helps to achieve the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals and boosts the EU’s competitiveness and growth. The program structure includes Excellent Science (European Research Council, Marie Sklodowska-Curie Actions, Research Infrastructures), Global Challenges and European Industrial Competitiveness (Health, Culture, Creativity and Inclusive Society, Civil Security for Society, Digital, Industry and Space, Climate, Energy and Mobility, Food, Bioeconomy, Natural Resources, Agriculture and Environment), and Innovative Europe (European Innovation Council, European Innovation Ecosystems, European Institute of Innovation and Technology).

description.value: The Horizon Europe strategic plan 2025-2027 steers research and innovation funding for the years 2025-2027, addressing key global challenges such as climate change, loss of biodiversity, the digital transition, and an ageing population. Open strategic autonomy and securing Europe’s leading role in developing and deploying critical technologies are overarching principles.

description.value: Work programmes set out funding opportunities under Horizon Europe. This overarching framework supports various initiatives including Marie Skłodowska-Curie actions, research infrastructures, European innovation ecosystems, and efforts to strengthen the European Research Area. It also encompasses specific programmes for the European Research Council, Joint Research Centre, and European Innovation Council, alongside institutionalised partnerships in key sectors like Mobility, Energy, Digital, and Bio-based economy. The program aims to foster research and innovation across Europe through diverse funding instruments and thematic clusters. The activities of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) and the European Defence Fund are also part of this framework.

The EU aims to create more connected and efficient innovation ecosystems to support the scaling up of companies, encourage innovation and stimulate cooperation among national, regional and local innovation actors. It contributes to all 3 key strategic orientations of the Horizon Europe strategic plan. It also supports the New European Innovation agenda, particularly flagships 2 and 3.

description.value: The Joint Research Centre (JRC) is the European Commission's science and knowledge service, employing scientists to provide independent scientific advice and support to EU policy. This area of Horizon Europe aims to generate high-quality scientific evidence for good public policies, supporting new initiatives and proposals for EU legislation. The JRC focuses its research on EU policy priorities, providing independent scientific evidence and technical support throughout the policy cycle. Funding opportunities related to these areas are available through the Horizon Europe work programmes.

project.value: All business sectors

Digital and automation technologies (rail), integrated air traffic management (ATM), disruptive new aircraft technologies, clean hydrogen technologies, zero-emission road transport technologies, connected, cooperative and automated mobility (CCAM) technologies, zero-emission solutions for waterborne transport, and industrial battery technology.

Europe's rail system, integrated air traffic management (ATM), clean aviation, clean hydrogen value chain, people-centric sustainable built environment (Built4People), zero-emission road transport (2ZERO), connected, cooperative and automated driving (CCAM), zero-emission waterborne transport, industrial battery value chain (Batt4EU), urban transitions (DUT), and clean energy transition.

impact.value: Delivering on European Green Deal objectives, achieving climate neutrality by 2050, net greenhouse gas (GHG) reductions (e.g., 30% for aviation, up to 90% with sustainable fuels, or zero CO2 with hydrogen), creating a sustainable, decarbonised and fully integrated energy system, high quality, low carbon, energy and resource efficient built environments, developing zero tailpipe emission transport, a climate neutral and clean road transport system, reducing carbon footprint through CCAM, enabling zero-emission waterborne transport by 2050, decarbonisation and elimination of other harmful emissions, more efficient and decarbonised use of energy, circular and environmental-friendly use of resources, and making Europe the first climate-neutral continent.

Improving the competitiveness of rail and supporting European technological leadership in rail, supporting the competitiveness and recovery of the European aviation sector, revitalising the built environment sector via sustainable operation, ensuring future European leadership in innovation, production and services for road transport, strengthening the competitiveness of European industries in growing green ship technology markets, supporting the development of a world-class European research and innovation ecosystem on batteries with a view towards industrial leadership, and supporting economic growth and European employment in the waterborne sector.

Driving urban transitions to a sustainable future with people-centric approaches, inducing behavioural change towards sustainable living, improving mobility and the safety of people and goods, demonstrating inclusive, user-oriented and well-integrated mobility concepts, and ensuring the well-being of citizens and preservation of biodiversity.

funding_details.value: Funds are intended to accelerate the development and deployment of innovative technologies, including digital and automation, disruptive new aircraft technologies, clean hydrogen technologies, zero tailpipe emission transport solutions, connected, cooperative and automated mobility (CCAM) technologies and services, zero-emission solutions for waterborne transport, and industrial battery value chain development.

description.value: European Partnerships under Horizon Europe aim to deliver on global challenges and modernise industry by pooling research and innovation investments from EU and associated countries, the private sector, foundations, and other stakeholders. These partnerships provide a framework for long-term, site-specific, multi-stakeholder experimentation, fostering collaboration to address critical challenges in areas like food, bioeconomy, natural resources, agriculture, and environment. They are designed to deliver ready-to-adopt practices and solutions, supporting the transformation of various sectors towards more sustainable and resilient systems.

description.value: The Euratom Research and Training Programme (2021-2025) is a complementary funding programme to Horizon Europe which covers nuclear research and innovation. It uses the same instruments and rules for participation as Horizon Europe. The programme aims to improve nuclear safety, security, safeguards, radiation protection, and waste management, while fostering fusion energy development and maintaining nuclear expertise within the community. It supports both direct actions by the Joint Research Centre and indirect actions by multi-partner consortia.

eligibility.value: Indirect actions are research activities undertaken by multi-partner consortia.
Focuses on the nuclear field, including nuclear research and innovation, nuclear fusion, nuclear fission, safety, and radiation protection.

financial.value: max. 1.5 million euros with another private investor

technical.value: For fusion research, the programme calls for a substantial reorganisation that will support a shift from pure, academic research to scientific questions of designing, building and operating future facilities such as the ITER tokamak.

ITER’s operation scenarios should be tested to ensure they are robust and have the required performance, requiring a broad experimental programme on existing fusion devices and an extensive analysis and simulation programme.
The focus for fusion research must gradually shift from physics to technology to achieve the goal of completing a conceptual demo design and starting the transition to an engineering design phase.

legal.value: The programme operates in line with the Euratom Treaty.
It uses the same instruments and rules for participation as Horizon Europe.

timeline.value: The Euratom Research and Training Programme runs for 5 years, from 2021 to 2025, to be extended in 2025 by 2 years to align with the EU's long-term budget 2021-2027.
Funding opportunities are set out in work programmes, such as the 2023-2025 and 2021-2022 Euratom Work Programmes.

description.value: This cluster responds to the challenges arising from persistent security threats, including cybercrime, as well as natural and man-made disasters. It aims to achieve impacts contained in the Horizon Europe strategic plan, focusing on disaster-resilient societies, protection and security, and cybersecurity. EU civil security research supports the European Commission’s guidelines for a safer and more secure Europe and stronger common borders. This research strengthens security research and innovation through the development of socially acceptable security technologies with added value for industrialisation and commercialisation.

eligibility.value: EU civil security research supports the European Commission’s guidelines and in particular the objectives of a safer and more secure Europe and of stronger common borders.

legal.value: Research in this cluster supports policies related to fighting crime and terrorism (including organised crime and cybercrime), border management (including customs security and maritime security), resilient infrastructure, cybersecurity (including security of network and information systems and certification), and disaster-resilient societies (including against chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) incidents, climate-related risks and extreme events, geological disasters, such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and tsunamis, pandemics).

timeline.value: Open deadline (rolling application)

geographic_eligibility.value: EU civil security research supports the European Commission's guidelines, implying eligibility for entities from EU member states and associated countries.

description.value: The European Research Council, set up by the EU in 2007, is the premiere European funding organisation for excellent frontier research. It provides attractive and flexible funding to enable talented and creative individual researchers, with an emphasis on early stage researchers, and their teams to pursue the most promising avenues at the frontier of science, on the basis of EU-wide competition based solely on the criterion of excellence. ERC grantees have already made advances in new and emerging technological fields, including clean and digital technologies, as well as in many other areas targeted by the key strategic orientations of the Horizon Europe strategic plan.

eligibility.value: talented and creative individual researchers, and their teams
EU-wide competition based solely on the criterion of excellence

timeline.value: ERC funding opportunities are set out in an annual work programme

application.value: All funding information and details on how to apply are on the Funding and Tenders portal.
based solely on the criterion of excellence

funding_details.value: to pursue the most promising avenues at the frontier of science

description.value: Widening Participation and Spreading Excellence actions under Horizon Europe contribute to building research and innovation capacity for countries lagging behind. They aim to strengthen potential for successful participation in transnational research and innovation processes, promote networking, and provide access to excellence. Participants in the programme will be able to upgrade their research and innovation systems, making them stronger and allowing the EU as a whole to advance together, in line with the policy objectives of the European Research Area.

eligibility.value: Countries lagging behind in research and innovation capacity (referred to as Widening countries), EU countries or Associated Countries.
Research institutions of Widening countries acting as coordinators, top-class leading counterparts at EU level, alliances of higher education institutions, Widening universities or research centres.

funding_details.value: For Teaming actions, securing complementary investment from structural funds or other sources is a condition.

Funds can be used to create new or modernise existing centres of excellence (Teaming), enhance networking activities, knowledge transfer and exchange of best practices (Twinning), engage with universities and empower them in research and innovation (EEI), support setting up interfaces between funding systems (Pathways to Synergies), improve dissemination and exploitation (Dissemination and Exploitation Support Facility), join ongoing research and innovation actions (Hop-on Facility), strengthen regional innovation excellence and ecosystems (Excellence Hubs), attract high-level researchers and establish research teams (ERA Chairs), boost interoperability of careers and employability of research and innovation talents (ERA Talents), and set-up research networks (COST).

timeline.value: Funding opportunities under Horizon Europe are set out in multiannual work programmes (e.g., 2023-25, 2025), indicating periodic calls for applications.

project.value: Building research and innovation capacity, transnational research and innovation processes, networking, access to excellence, upgrading research and innovation systems, European Research Area, science and value creation, cross-border collaboration, knowledge diffusion, technology uptake, spill-over effects, regional innovation excellence, innovation ecosystems, interoperability of careers, employability of research and innovation talents, cross-sectoral talent circulation, academia-business collaboration, knowledge transfer.
Projects can be in a scientific domain of choice (ERA Chairs) or a wide range of scientific topics (COST), implying broad applicability.

restrictions.value: Twinning actions require linking at least two research institutions from 2 different EU countries or Associated Countries. European Excellence Initiative involves cooperation in alliances of higher education institutions. Excellence Hubs strengthen innovation ecosystems by teaming up and creating robust linkages between academia, businesses, governments, and civil society.

description.value: The Euratom Research and Training Programme (2021-2025) is a complementary funding programme to Horizon Europe which covers nuclear research and innovation. It uses the same instruments and rules for participation as Horizon Europe. The programme has direct and indirect actions, with indirect actions being research activities undertaken by multi-partner consortia. Its objectives include improving nuclear safety, security, and radiation protection, fostering fusion energy development, and maintaining nuclear expertise within the community.

eligibility.value: Indirect actions are research activities undertaken by multi-partner consortia.

financial.value: The Euratom programme funds 2 prizes for researchers: SOFT Innovation Prize and Nuclear Innovation Prize.

legal.value: The programme is in line with the Euratom Treaty.

timeline.value: The programme will run for 5 years, from 2021 to 2025, to be extended in 2025 by 2 years in order to be aligned with the EU's long term budget 2021-2027.

description.value: European Partnerships are strategic instruments within Horizon Europe, enabling long-term collaboration between the EU's various partners. They bring together the European Commission and private and/or public partners to address Europe’s most pressing challenges through concerted research and innovation initiatives. These partnerships are a key implementation tool of Horizon Europe, contributing significantly to achieving the EU’s political priorities, such as the green and digital transitions, by pooling resources and avoiding duplication of investments.

eligibility.value: Partnerships involve the European Commission and private and/or public partners, including research and innovation funders, other public authorities, and industry associations.

funding_details.value: For co-funded partnerships, partners generally implement joint transnational calls as well as additional activities, with either 30% or 50% co-funding from Horizon Europe.
Funds are used for joint programmes of research and innovation activities and the mobilisation of additional activities by partners.

financial.value: max. 1.5 million euros with another private investor

Support for community building and mutual learning across partnerships, raising visibility and strengthening stakeholder communication and consultation, and providing policy makers and partnerships with a better evidence base.

legal.value: Institutionalised European Partnerships (Article 185 and 187 initiatives) require the adoption of specific legislation and are implemented by dedicated structures created for that purpose.

timeline.value: Partnerships enable long-term collaboration. The first Horizon Europe strategic plan identified 29 co-funded and co-programmed partnerships to be launched between 2021-2024. The Partnership for Research and Innovation in the Mediterranean Area (PRIMA) is continued under Horizon Europe for the period 2025-2027. The Horizon Europe strategic plan 2025-2027 includes additional candidate partnerships to be launched during the second half of Horizon Europe.
Additional candidate co-funded and co-programmed partnerships are to be launched during the second half of Horizon Europe.

description.value: The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) is an independent EU body dedicated to increasing Europe’s ability to innovate by nurturing entrepreneurial talent and supporting new ideas. It plays a key role in Horizon Europe's Pillar III ‘Innovative Europe’, focusing on supporting disruptive and market-creating innovations. The EIT aims to strengthen sustainable innovation ecosystems across Europe and foster entrepreneurial and innovation skills through a lifelong learning perspective. It also works to bring new solutions to global societal challenges to the market.

description.value: The Joint Research Centre (JRC) is the European Commission's science and knowledge service which employs scientists to carry out research in order to provide independent scientific advice and support to EU policy. The aim of this area of Horizon Europe is to generate high-quality scientific evidence for good public policies. The JRC will provide EU policies with independent scientific evidence and technical support throughout the policy cycle, focusing its research on EU policy priorities. This work programme supports a number of the orientations defined in the Horizon Europe strategic plan.

geographic.value: The program focuses on providing scientific advice and support to EU policies, with intervention areas including support for EU countries and regions.

description.value: This cluster aims at reducing environmental degradation, halting and reversing the decline of biodiversity on land, inland waters and sea and better managing natural resources through transformative changes of the economy and society in both urban and rural areas. It will ensure food and nutrition security for all within planetary boundaries through knowledge, innovation and digitalisation in agriculture, fisheries, aquaculture and food systems. The program also seeks to steer and accelerate the transition to a low carbon, resource efficient circular economy and sustainable bioeconomy, including forestry. Research and innovation activities under cluster 6 will contribute to the objectives of the European Green Deal, including the Biodiversity Strategy to 2030, the Farm to Fork strategy, and the European Climate Pact.

description.value: This Horizon Europe cluster aims to reduce environmental degradation, reverse biodiversity decline, and improve natural resource management through transformative changes in the economy and society. It seeks to ensure food and nutrition security for all within planetary boundaries using knowledge, innovation, and digitalisation in agriculture, fisheries, aquaculture, and food systems. The program also focuses on accelerating the transition to a low-carbon, resource-efficient circular economy and sustainable bioeconomy, including forestry. Research and innovation activities contribute to the European Green Deal objectives, including the Biodiversity Strategy to 2030, Farm to Fork strategy, and European Climate Pact.

description.value: Horizon Europe's Cluster 3 focuses on civil security for society, addressing challenges from persistent security threats, including cybercrime, and natural and man-made disasters. The program aims to contribute to a safer and more secure Europe with stronger common borders, supporting research and innovation in critical security areas. It supports policies related to fighting crime and terrorism, border management, resilient infrastructure, and cybersecurity.

description.value: The European Research Council, set up by the EU in 2007, is the premiere European funding organisation for excellent frontier research. It provides attractive and flexible funding to enable talented and creative individual researchers, with an emphasis on early stage researchers, and their teams to pursue the most promising avenues at the frontier of science. Funding is awarded on the basis of EU-wide competition based solely on the criterion of excellence. ERC grantees have already made advances in new and emerging technological fields, including clean and digital technologies, as well as in many other areas targeted by the key strategic orientations of the Horizon Europe strategic plan.

description.value: European Partnerships under Horizon Europe aim to deliver on global challenges and modernise industry by fostering collaboration between the EU, associated countries, the private sector, foundations, and other stakeholders. These partnerships support innovative SMEs in developing products, processes, and services through funding market-led, cross-border, research and innovation collaborative projects. The initiative also provides accompanying measures to enable global collaboration and the commercialisation of new knowledge, thereby helping innovative SMEs grow and integrate into global value chains and new markets.

eligibility.value: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with a focus on research and innovation.
Cooperation of 2 or more international partners is required, with at least one research and innovation SME acting as a leader.

project.value: Delivering on global challenges and modernising industry, developing products, processes and services, fostering global collaboration and commercialising new knowledge, deploying and consolidating an open, trusted virtual environment for research data (European Open Science Cloud), mitigating or adapting to climate change, accelerating deployment of new solutions to market, building a sustainable energy sector, driving digital innovation and entrepreneurial talent, enabling European citizens to live longer, healthier lives, developing a highly skilled food sector and healthier lifestyles, transforming industrial production towards knowledge-intensive, sustainable, low-emission, trans-sectoral manufacturing, boosting competitiveness, growth and attractiveness of the European raw materials sector, developing a greener, more inclusive, safer and smarter urban transport system, improving competitiveness and innovation capabilities in cultural and creative industries.
Advanced data infrastructures, digital innovation.

description.value: The European Research Council, set up by the EU in 2007, is the premiere European funding organisation for excellent frontier research. It provides attractive and flexible funding to enable talented and creative individual researchers, with an emphasis on early stage researchers, and their teams to pursue the most promising avenues at the frontier of science, on the basis of EU-wide competition based solely on the criterion of excellence. ERC grantees have already made advances in new and emerging technological fields, including clean and digital technologies, as well as in many other areas targeted by the key strategic orientations of the Horizon Europe strategic plan.

description.value: The EU Mission on Adaptation to Climate Change aims to support at least 150 European regions and communities towards climate resilience by 2030. It focuses on helping these regions and local authorities to understand climate risks, develop adaptation pathways, and implement innovative solutions. This Mission is crucial as climate change affects various regions, economic sectors, and societal groups differently, necessitating enhanced preparedness to cope with its effects and adapt our way of living. The Mission also contributes to delivering the European Green Deal.

description.value: EU Missions are large-scale initiatives under Horizon Europe setting clear, time-bound goals that drive focused efforts towards some of our greatest challenges such as climate change, cancer, ocean restoration, soil health, and the development of climate-neutral and smart cities. By bringing together researchers, policymakers, citizens, and stakeholders, EU Missions pool the necessary resources to drive innovation and deliver concrete solutions for societal benefit. These missions are a novelty of the Horizon Europe research and innovation programme for 2021-2027.

timeline.value: The Horizon Europe research and innovation programme runs from 2021 to 2027. Missions aim to achieve their specific goals by 2030.

geographic.value: Initiatives and solutions are focused on Europe, including European cities, to enable all European cities to follow suit.

description.value: The conference 'Research and Innovation for a Competitive Green Transition' was hosted by the Directorate-General for Research and Innovation of the European Commission. It served as a dynamic forum to explore how research and innovation accelerate Europe’s green transformation and strengthen its global competitiveness. The event showcased R&I solutions that enhance citizens’ quality of life and support the European Green Deal. Discussions highlighted robust EU funding instruments, such as Horizon Europe and the European Innovation Council (EIC), as vital enablers for financing the green transition and achieving 2030 climate targets. The conference also featured innovative projects supporting climate neutrality, green transition, and environmental restoration, covering diverse themes from zero food waste to circular economy.

geographic.value: Participants and topics discussed were from across Europe and beyond, indicating a broad geographic scope for the underlying R&I activities.

The Life Sciences funding offer is limited to one project per research category per company.

description.value: The R&D Infrastructure Funding Programme supports projects designed to acquire and develop high quality R&D infrastructure for use in both basic and applied research. Throughout European research, R&D infrastructures play an essential role in generating new knowledge and technologies in all scientific disciplines. They provide an important basis for state-of-the-art research, and can act as hubs for cooperative R&D. The FFG launched its R&D infrastructure funding initiative in 2016, intended to strengthen Austria as a location for excellence in research, both for businesses as well as universities and research establishments, and consequently to improve the international standing of Austrian research.

eligibility.value: Institutions for research and knowledge dissemination (universities, universities of applied sciences, non-university research institutions), other non-commercial institutions, enterprises, (Non-profit) Associations, Competence centres, Large companies, Multipliers / Intermediaries, Research facilities, Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), Universities, Universities of applied sciences.

The funding is targeted at supporting universities and research establishments in profile building and development planning, establishing new and promising fields of research, supporting companies in establishing and extending industrial R&D infrastructures, and creating incentives for the coordinated joint acquisition and use of R&D infrastructure by research establishments and businesses.

timeline.value: The program is available from 20.04.2016 to 31.12.2029.

geographic.value: The program aims to strengthen Austria as a location for excellence in research, implying entities based in Austria.

project.value: Generating new knowledge and technologies in all scientific disciplines, state-of-the-art research, and cooperative R&D.

funding_details.value: Funds can be used to acquire and develop high quality R&D infrastructure for use in both basic and applied research, establish and extend industrial R&D infrastructures, and for coordinated joint acquisition and use of R&D infrastructure.

description.value: The FFG initiative for the promotion of R&D infrastructure, launched in 2016, aims to strengthen the basis for excellent research in Austria for companies, universities, and research institutions, thereby improving the international positioning of Austrian research. R&D infrastructures play an essential role in the European Research Area for generating new knowledge and technologies across all scientific fields. They serve as a crucial foundation for state-of-the-art research and can act as hubs for cooperative R&D. The R&D infrastructure funding supports projects for the acquisition and establishment of high-quality R&D infrastructure for basic research as well as application-oriented research.

The funding has no thematic restrictions on specific technology or scientific areas.

impact.value: The program aims to improve the international positioning of Austrian research and support companies in building and expanding economically utilized R&D infrastructures.

The program supports the profile building and development planning of universities and research institutions to establish new future-oriented research fields, and creates incentives for the coordinated joint acquisition and use of R&D infrastructure by research institutions and companies.

funding_details.value: Funds can be used for the acquisition and establishment of high-quality R&D infrastructure for basic research and application-oriented research, including building and expanding economically utilized R&D infrastructures.
Funds are intended for capital expenditures related to the acquisition and establishment of R&D infrastructure.

restrictions.value: The planned use of the R&D infrastructure must be entirely assigned to either economic or non-economic use.

eligibility.value: Institutions for research and knowledge dissemination (universities, universities of applied sciences, non-university research institutions), other non-commercial institutions, and enterprises. This includes (Non-profit) Associations, Competence centres, Large companies, Multipliers / Intermediaries, Research facilities, Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), Universities, and Universities of applied sciences.

The funding is targeted at supporting universities and research establishments in profile building and development planning, establishing new and promising fields of research, supporting companies in establishing and extending industrial R&D infrastructures, and creating incentives for the coordinated joint acquisition and use of R&D infrastructure by research establishments and businesses.

timeline.value: The program is available from 20.04.2016 to 31.12.2029.

geographic.value: The program is intended to strengthen Austria as a location for excellence in research.

project.value: Generating new knowledge and technologies in all scientific disciplines, and state-of-the-art research.

timeline.value: Applications can be submitted between October 1, 2025, and September 30, 2026, 12:00 PM.

application.value: Project submission is exclusively electronic via eCall. The submission includes the content description, work plan (with work packages, project management elements like GANTT chart, tasks, milestones, results), organization description (expertise of participants, results from other projects, project-relevant infrastructure), and costs and financing. The application can be submitted in German or English.
Applications must be submitted electronically via eCall.
The dissertation must demonstrate a clear economic application relevance.
Doctoral candidates must be enrolled in a doctoral program for the entire project duration and employed for the project at the funded organization for at least 860 hours per year.
Mentoring is provided by the applicant organization, while scientific supervision is provided by a university with the right to award doctorates.
Project start must occur within one year of submission.

funding_details.value: Funds can be used for application-oriented research projects, primarily covering personnel costs for highly qualified junior researchers, and travel costs for doctoral candidates. Eligible costs also include third-party costs, plant usage costs, material and other costs.

restrictions.value: For companies, a maximum of two applications (including affiliated organizations) can be approved in this call.
The call may close before the end of the submission period if budget funds are fully or partially exhausted.
Approximately 50% of the funds are reserved for female doctoral candidates to promote equal opportunities.

description.value: The SPORTS RESEARCH LAB TIROL is a joint research initiative of four Tyrolean universities: LFU Universität Innsbruck, MCI Management Center Innsbruck, FH Kufstein Tirol, and UMIT Tirol. It combines the expertise of renowned Tyrolean universities, offering insights into current research and providing scientifically verified numbers, data, and facts from a single source. The initiative aims to build a comprehensive, statewide data pool on sport and movement, serving as a crucial basis for decisions related to Alpine sports. By providing relevant information for Tirol's sports location, projects can be assessed against statewide overall strategies. The concrete implementation of these projects has the potential to contribute specifically to the desired ecological, social, and infrastructural development of Tirol.

geographic.value: The initiative focuses on the region of Tirol, Austria, involving Tyrolean universities and building a statewide data pool for the development of Tirol.

timeline.value: The Circularity Check process includes a 30-minute preliminary talk, a 3-hour on-site check, and a 1-hour online follow-up meeting.

application.value: Interested companies must express their interest via email, followed by a short, non-binding online preliminary talk (approx. 30 minutes). The Circularity Check is then conducted on-site at the company or at Standortagentur Tirol (approx. 3 hours), concluded by an online follow-up meeting with results presentation and discussion of measures (approx. 1 hour).

financial.value: The participation in the Circularity Check is free of charge. Companies also benefit from access to an expert network and further events within the Circular Hub Tirol.

description.value: The Circular Hub Tirol serves as the central point of contact for the circular economy in Tirol, supporting the transition to a circular economic system. The network also acts as an interface for knowledge transfer, aiming to deeply embed the economic, ecological, and social relevance of the circular economy into Tirol's economic life by 2030.

It leverages expertise in economy, technology, creative industries, culture, social innovations, energy, mobility, cooperation, and governance. The program aims to strengthen regions in global competition and find new solutions for future challenges, offering service-oriented, independent, neutral, integrated, versatile, and individual support. The Alpine Technologien Tirol - ATT GmbH is not dependent on follow-up orders due to its business model, ensuring neutrality. Depending on the need, architects, geographers, lawyers, economists, and spatial planners are available to provide integrated solutions.

project.value: The program focuses on sustainability as a key success factor for businesses, covering environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) aspects. It analyzes 24 criteria across four dimensions: economic (market development, growth, innovation management, digitalization, resilience), ecological (resource reduction, biodiversity, circular economy, energy, regenerative energies, mobility, GHG emissions), social (training, employee involvement, diversity, health, social engagement), and management (sustainability strategy, ESG standards, sustainable innovation, procurement, supply chains, partnerships, communication).

description.value: This page describes the EIC Fund Board of Directors, which is vested with the broadest powers of the EIC Fund. The Board is composed of five members appointed by the European Commission, including both officials and independent directors. It outlines the current composition of the EIC Fund Board, listing its chair and other directors.

The EIC Prizes are annual recognition awards that celebrate Europe's leading innovators and innovative solutions. These prizes aim to promote innovation within communities, recognize women entrepreneurs, and encourage innovation procurement across Europe. They also incentivize and reward early-stage ideas in social innovation and innovative solutions that enhance humanitarian support. Additionally, the EIC promotes Horizon Prizes for innovative solutions to broader societal challenges.

description.value: The EIC Summit 2025 is a flagship event organised by the European Innovation Council, designed to bring together Europe's leading innovators, scientists, entrepreneurs, investors, and policymakers. This two-day summit offers inspiring plenary speeches, visionary insights, and extensive networking opportunities. It includes dedicated workshops for EIC beneficiaries on topics such as investments, intellectual property, and scaling up companies, and features the celebration of the EIC Prizes awards.

eligibility.value: Day 1 (2 April 2025) is an invitation-only day, exclusively for EIC beneficiaries.
Day 2 (3 April 2025) is a flagship event, open to all interested stakeholders.

timeline.value: The EIC Summit 2025 takes place over two days, from 2 April 2025 to 3 April 2025.
Registration is required to download the dedicated EIC Summit networking app and schedule meetings.

geographic.value: The EIC Summit 2025 will take place in the historical Tour & Taxis site on the Brussels Canal, Brussels, Belgium.

documents.value: A full business plan (maximum 50 pages), including information on the company’s ownership and financial structure and a justification on the STEP related objectives; A pitch-deck (maximum 15 pages); A pre-commitment from a single qualified investor (according to the official template, representing at least 20% of the total target funding round, which must range between EUR 50 to 150 million, and be at least 3-5 times the EIC investment); A financial plan and agreement document (according to the template); Results of the freedom to operate (FTO) analysis (or a note of maximum 2 pages outlining FTO if no full analysis, or a simple statement if FTO is not relevant); CVs of key personnel.
Business plan: maximum 50 pages; Pitch-deck: maximum 15 pages in PDF format; FTO analysis note: maximum 2 pages.

description.value: The 'State programmes' initiative by Standortagentur Tirol offers customised funding and support services for companies, R&D institutes, and universities in Tyrol. It focuses on innovation and technology development, aiming to strengthen the competitive position of Tyrolean businesses and foster knowledge transfer. The program supports various research, technological, and innovation projects, including cooperative ventures between businesses and scientific institutes.

geographic_eligibility.value: Companies, R&D institutes, and universities based in Tyrol, Austria.

description.value: The EU program Erasmus+ provides financial support for students, university graduates, pupils, apprentices, and young workers for their internships abroad. This seven-year program, with a budget of approximately 26 billion Euros, aims to enhance competence levels and employability, promote lifelong learning, enable sustainable growth, strengthen social cohesion and European identity, and drive innovation. The current program generation from 2021 to 2027 focuses on inclusion and diversity, digitalization, political education, and sustainability.

eligibility.value: The program supports students and university graduates.
The program supports pupils, apprentices, and young workers.
For the specific project 'TirolerInnen auf der Walz', the target group includes Tyrolean pupils from vocational schools (BMHS), Tyrolean apprentices, and newly qualified skilled workers.
Students and graduates from Tyrolean universities are funded through their respective sending university.

timeline.value: The program generation runs from 2021 to 2027.

description.value: This program, part of the European Education Program ERASMUS+, supports individuals from Tyrol, Austria, in undertaking internships abroad within the EU. It aims to help apprentices, young employees, and students from vocational schools gain professional experience, deepen their knowledge and skills, and broaden their professional and personal horizons through funded international internships. The service offers initial information, assistance in finding suitable placements, support with applications for internships and scholarships, and serves as a point of contact during the stay abroad.

eligibility.value: Applicants must be Tyrolean apprentices, young employees, students from Tyrolean vocational secondary and higher schools, university students, or university graduates.

geographic_eligibility.value: Applicants must be from Tyrol, Austria. Internships must take place within the European Union.

application.value: The service provides initial information, assistance in finding suitable internship placements, support with applying for an internship, support with applying for a scholarship, and acts as a point of contact during the stay abroad.
Application portal for ERASMUS+ internships abroad.

eligibility.value: Applicants must be employees with completed vocational training (apprenticeship or BMHS) and have their residence in Tyrol.
The internship should be completed within one year after the vocational training completion (LAP).
Young employees under 18 years of age require a declaration of consent from their parents to participate in the mobility program.

Internships at institutions that manage EU community programs or are financed by EU funds (e.g., European administrative bodies like ministries, the European Parliament, the European Commission), as well as representative bodies of social partners and foreign representations of the participants' countries of origin (cultural institutes, embassies, consulates, foreign trade chambers), are not funded.

description.value: The Eureka Network provides a gateway for applying to various international R&D and innovation funding programmes. This page guides applicants to specific sub-programmes such as Eurostars, Globalstars, Innowwide, and Eureka Clusters. Each programme has its own application portal and specific calls, often requiring prior contact with a National Funding Body for country-specific requirements and additional steps.

eligibility.value: Applicants must contact the National Funding Body in their respective country, as these bodies are responsible for funding within the Eureka programmes and may have extra steps or specific requirements before an application can be made through Eureka.

timeline.value: Applications are only possible when there is an active call open for the selected programme. Applicants should check the specific programme page for currently open calls.

geographic_eligibility.value: Eligibility is tied to countries participating in the Eureka Network programmes, requiring applicants to engage with their National Funding Body.

project.value: The Eureka Network supports international R&D and innovation projects. Eureka Clusters are industry-led communities focused on specific technology areas.
Eureka Clusters are focused on specific technology areas, with examples including CELTIC-NEXT, EUROGIA2030, ITEA 4, SMART, and Xecs.

application.value: To apply for funding, applicants must first select the desired programme (e.g., Eurostars, Globalstars, Innowwide, Eureka Clusters, Network Projects, Investment Readiness, Fast Track to the EIC Accelerator). Each programme directs applicants to a specific application portal or platform.

Applications are submitted through specific portals: the Eureka Project Management Platform for Eurostars, the Eureka Application Portal for Globalstars and Innowwide, individual Eureka Cluster websites for Cluster programmes, and the Fast Track to the EIC Accelerator platform for that specific programme.
Applicants must contact their National Funding Body before applying, as these bodies may have additional steps or requirements specific to their country.

description.value: The Eureka Network is an intergovernmental organisation that supports market-driven R&D and innovation projects across various sectors. It provides a platform for businesses, research centres, and universities to collaborate internationally on innovative projects. The network offers different programmes, such as Clusters, Eurostars, Globalstars, and Network Projects, to help participants access funding and support for their R&D initiatives.

description.value: You are a start-up or want to found a company. Here you will find information on obtaining equity and debt capital. With the Finance Navigator, you get an overview of who will support you financially in the different founding phases. With just a few clicks, you can identify which capital sources are available to you before, during, and after the company formation, and who can support you in the different phases.

eligibility.value: Start-ups and aspiring entrepreneurs who want to found a company.

The Finance Navigator supports companies across all founding phases: Orientierung (Pre-Seed) for idea generation and product/idea assessment; Vorgründung (Seed) for concept development, market analysis, basic development, and business plan creation; Gründung for company formation, business plan, marketing concept, product development, and market entry preparation; Markteintritt (Early Stage) for going-to-market with a finished product and sales; Aufbau (1st Stage) for company development, market penetration, and image building; Wachstum (2nd Stage) for company growth, expansion, and striving for market leadership; Reife (3rd Stage) for company maturity, stabilization, optimization, or potential exit.

funding_details.value: The capital sources identified through the navigator can be used for various purposes depending on the company stage, including idea generation, product and idea assessment, product concept, market analysis, basic development, business plan creation, marketing concept, product development, market entry preparation, sales, market penetration, image building, expansion, stabilization, and optimization.

application.value: Users must first select the phase in which their company or its formation is currently located to receive tailored information on capital sources.

description.value: The WKO Upper Austria funding portal provides an overview of various funding programs designed to support companies in different stages of their development. These programs offer assistance for company founding, business development, technology adoption for efficiency, legal security, and industry-specific productivity enhancements. Companies can use a funding navigator to find suitable offers. The portal serves as a central hub for Upper Austrian businesses seeking financial and advisory support.

description.value: The call supports application-oriented research projects carried out by PhD candidates employed at non-university research institutions or companies of any size with R&D activities, each with a branch in Austria. The project must demonstrate clear economic relevance and benefit the Austrian economy, strengthening cooperation between science and industry. Funding primarily covers personnel costs for highly qualified early-career researchers, aiming to retain them long term for the Austrian research and innovation system and open career paths outside academia. Around 50% of the funds are reserved for female PhD candidates to promote equal opportunities.

eligibility.value: Eligible applicants are non-university research institutions or companies of any size with R&D activities. The target group also includes Competence centres, Large companies, Research facilities, Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and Start Ups.
